TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ProgressBar extends Android.Views.View

remarks.para: Visual indicator of progress in some operation. Displays a bar to the user representing how far the operation has progressed; the application can change the amount of progress (modifying the length of the bar) as it moves forward. There is also a secondary progress displayable on a progress bar which is useful for displaying intermediate progress, such as the buffer level during a streaming playback progress bar.

A progress bar can also be made indeterminate. In indeterminate mode, the progress bar shows a cyclic animation without an indication of progress. This mode is used by applications when the length of the task is unknown. The indeterminate progress bar can be either a spinning wheel or a horizontal bar.

To add a progress bar to a layout file, you can use the <ProgressBar> element. By default, the progress bar is a spinning wheel (an indeterminate indicator). To change to a horizontal progress bar, apply the style, like so:

If you will use the progress bar to show real progress, you must use the horizontal bar. You can then increment the progress with or . By default, the progress bar is full when it reaches 100. If necessary, you can adjust the maximum value (the value for a full bar) using the attribute. Other attributes available are listed below.

Another common style to apply to the progress bar is , which shows a smaller version of the spinning wheel—useful when waiting for content to load. For example, you can insert this kind of progress bar into your default layout for a view that will be populated by some content fetched from the Internet—the spinning wheel appears immediately and when your application receives the content, it replaces the progress bar with the loaded content. For example:

example.code: <LinearLayout android:orientation="horizontal" ... > <ProgressBar android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" style="@android:style/Widget.ProgressBar.Small" android:layout_marginRight="5dp" /> <TextView android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:text="@string/loading" /> </LinearLayout>

remarks.para: Other progress bar styles provided by the system include:
The "inverse" styles provide an inverse color scheme for the spinner, which may be necessary if your application uses a light colored theme (a white background).
See ,

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool Indeterminate { get; set; }
.property instance bool Indeterminate

Docs.summary: Indicate whether this progress bar is in indeterminate mode.

remarks.para: Indicate whether this progress bar is in indeterminate mode.

Set method documentation [Android Documentation]
If this progress bar's style only supports indeterminate mode (such as the circular progress bars), then this will be ignored.
Change the indeterminate mode for this progress bar. In indeterminate mode, the progress is ignored and the progress bar shows an infinite animation instead.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual Android.OS.IParcelable OnSaveInstanceState ();
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class Android.OS.IParcelable OnSaveInstanceState() cil managed

Docs.summary: Hook allowing a view to generate a representation of its internal state that can later be used to create a new instance with that same state.

remarks.para: Hook allowing a view to generate a representation of its internal state that can later be used to create a new instance with that same state. This state should only contain information that is not persistent or can not be reconstructed later. For example, you will never store your current position on screen because that will be computed again when a new instance of the view is placed in its view hierarchy.

Some examples of things you may store here: the current cursor position in a text view (but usually not the text itself since that is stored in a content provider or other persistent storage), the currently selected item in a list view.

Docs.summary: Returns the tint applied to the progress background, if specified.

remarks.para:
Get method documentation [Android Documentation]
Returns the tint applied to the progress background, if specified.

Set method documentation [Android Documentation]
Applies a tint to the progress background, if one exists. Does not modify the current tint mode, which is by default.
The progress background must be specified as a layer with id in a used as the progress drawable.
Subsequent calls to where the drawable contains a progress background will automatically mutate the drawable and apply the specified tint and tint mode using .

Docs.summary: Returns the tint applied to the progress drawable, if specified.

remarks.para:
Get method documentation [Android Documentation]
Returns the tint applied to the progress drawable, if specified.

Set method documentation [Android Documentation]
Applies a tint to the progress indicator, if one exists, or to the entire progress drawable otherwise. Does not modify the current tint mode, which is by default.
The progress indicator should be specified as a layer with id in a used as the progress drawable.
Subsequent calls to will automatically mutate the drawable and apply the specified tint and tint mode using .

remarks.para: This property is used to control which jclass is provided to methods like .

MemberSignature.Value: protected override Type ThresholdType { get; }
.property instance class System.Type ThresholdType

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which provides the declaring type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control virtual vs. non virtual method dispatch against the underlying JNI object. When this property is equal to the declaring type, then virtual method invocation against the JNI object is performed; otherwise, we assume that the method was overridden by a derived type, and perform non-virtual methdo invocation.
